result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

4:21 PM Prosecuting attorney Robert J Jambois in court for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant Kiaran D. Coit in court.  Attorney Jevon Jones Jaconi appeared by video for Kiaran D. Coit. 

Atty Jambois makes statements to the court regarding Atty Jaconi being ordered to appear in person. 
Court reviewed the Motion to Withdraw and wanted to address this on the record. 
Atty Jaconi makes arguments to the court in support of his motion to withdraw. 
Court notes the public defender had a difficult time finding counsel.  Questions Atty Jaconi about proceeding via zoom with the preliminary hearing.  Further questions Atty Jaconi regarding in person appearances.  
BY THE COURT:  Court denies the request to withdraw.  Most hearings can be done by phone or zoom with the exception of substantive hearings. 

Atty Jambois questions if the defendant will waive the attorney appearing on zoom. 
Defendant would not like to proceed without his attorney present. 
Atty Jambois makes arguments to the court.  
Atty Jaconi makes arguments to the court. 
Court addresses the parties.  

Court will reschedule this preliminary hearing where the defendant, defense counsel and the witness be in person. 
State has complied with Victim Notification Statutes.
Atty Jambois indicates the victims have been present for each hearing. 
Court questions Atty Jaconi regarding discussing a waiver of preliminary hearing.
